questions.text: A patient has red, painful skin without blisters after sun exposure. What degree of burn is this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

First-degree (superficial) burn → only epidermis, red, dry, painful (like sunburn), no blistering.

questions.text: n an adult, a burn involving the anterior trunk and anterior surface of both legs would account for approximately:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

36%

Explanation:
• Anterior trunk = 18%
• Front of each leg = 9%
→ Total = 18% + 9% + 9% = 36%

choices.text: 32-year-old with 8% superficial burns on the back
45-year-old with 12% partial-thickness burns on the thigh

questions.text: Which of the following patients should be referred to a burns center?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

45-year-old with 12% partial-thickness burns on the thigh

Explanation: >10% TBSA partial-thickness burn → referral criteria

questions.text: A 25-year-old male, 60 kg, with 40% burns. Fluid in first 8 hrs by Parkland?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

4800 mL

4×60×40 = 9600 mL → 4800 in 8 hrs

questions.text: Most preventable deaths in trauma occur in which phase of trimodal distribution?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Phase II

questions.text: In START triage, a patient breathing 35/min with capillary refill less than 2 sec is categorized as:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Red

A patient with a respiratory rate of 35 breaths per minute would be categorized as Immediate (Red) in the START (Simple Triage and Rapid Treatment) triage system.

The START triage algorithm is designed to quickly assess and categorize patients based on the severity of their injuries. The first step after identifying the "walking wounded" (Green) is to check for respirations. If a patient is breathing, their respiratory rate is assessed. A respiratory rate greater than 30 breaths per minute is an immediate trigger for the Immediate (Red) category. This finding alone is sufficient to categorize the patient, as it indicates a severe life-threatening condition such as shock or respiratory distress. Therefore, the second part of the assessment—the capillary refill time—is not even considered in this case, as the high respiratory rate has already placed the patient in the highest priority group. . The purpose of this system is to prioritize care for the most critical patients who can still benefit from immediate intervention, while not spending excessive time on any single patient during a mass casualty incident.

questions.text: A patient with a closed femur fracture, vitals stable, GCS 15 — category is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Yellow

questions.text: In ATLS, first step for an unconscious trauma patient is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Secure airway with C-spine control

questions.text: Which hormone is elevated during the ebb and catabolic phase of trauma?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

questions.text: Which trauma score includes GCS, SBP, and RR?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

RTS

questions.text: Retroperitoneal hematoma in pelvic trauma (Zone III) is best managed by:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: Le Fort fracture type II involves which structure?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: Most common zone involved in penetrating neck trauma?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: Most common fatal injury in primary blast:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: Most common organ injured in penetrating abdominal trauma:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: Which of the following clinical signs is most suggestive of an anterior cranial fossa fracture?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

CSF rhinorrhea

questions.text: CSF leak is confirmed by which of the following tests?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Beta-2 transferrin assay

Beta-2 transferrin is a CSF-specific protein — most accurate and specific test.

questions.text: Crescent-shaped hematoma on CT scan is most likely:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Subdural hematoma

choices.text: Coup is always more severe than contrecoup
Contrecoup occurs opposite to site of impact
Seen commonly in falls and MVAs

questions.text: Which of the following statements about coup–contrecoup injury is FALSE?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Coup is always more severe than contrecoup

Contrecoup can be more severe, especially in falls where occipital lobe slams the skull.

choices.text: CN III palsy, hemiparesis, decreased consciousness

questions.text: Which of the following triads is classic for uncal herniation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

CN III palsy, hemiparesis, decreased consciousness

Uncal herniation triad: fixed dilated pupil, contralateral (or paradoxical ipsilateral) hemiparesis, decreased GCS.

questions.text: A GCS score of 8 or less indicates:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Coma/severe brain injury

“Less than 8, intubate” is a key rule — GCS ≤8 = comatose

questions.text: Which of the following structures lies along the left sagittal fissure of the liver?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Ligamentum venosum and ligamentum teres

The left sagittal fissure separates the left lobe of the liver from:
• Caudate lobe (Segment I) — posteriorly
• Quadrate lobe (Segment IV) — anteriorly
It is a landmark in liver anatomy and used in surgery to orient the left lobe.
B. Gallbladder and IVC → These lie in the right sagittal fissure
(aka main portal fissure – includes gallbladder fossa anteriorly & IVC posteriorly)
C. Caudate and quadrate lobes → These lie adjacent to the left sagittal fissure, but not in it.
D. Right hepatic vein → Runs between anterior and posterior segments of right lobe, not related to left sagittal fissure

questions.text: The Pringle maneuver involves occlusion of which structure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Hepatoduodenal ligament

This ligament contains the portal triad: common bile duct (right), hepatic artery (left), and portal vein (posterior).
The Pringle maneuver clamps the hepatoduodenal ligament, which contains the portal triad (portal vein, hepatic artery, and bile duct).
If bleeding continues despite Pringle maneuver, the source is likely retrohepatic IVC or hepatic veins, which are not compressed by the maneuver.

questions.text: According to Couinaud classification, the liver is divided into:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

8 segments

Each with its own portal triad & hepatic vein drainage

questions.text: A patient with fever, RUQ pain, and anchovy sauce pus on aspiration most likely has:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Amoebic liver abscess

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is used in the treatment of hydatid cyst?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Albendazole

Pre- and post-op to sterilize cyst and prevent recurrence.

questions.text: A liver lesion with “spoke wheel appearance” on contrast imaging is most likely:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

FNH

questions.text: Fibrolamellar HCC typically occurs in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Young adults without cirrhosis

Mean age ~25 years; no underlying liver disease

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of portal hypertension worldwide?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Cirrhosis

Explanation: Cirrhosis is the leading cause of portal HTN globally due to fibrotic distortion of hepatic architecture increasing intrahepatic resistance.

choices.text: Hepatic vein and inferior vena cava

questions.text: TIPS is done between which of the following vessels?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Hepatic vein and portal vein

TIPS connects portal vein to hepatic vein, bypassing the fibrotic liver and reducing portal pressure.
TIPS is a minimally invasive, radiologically placed shunt between the portal and hepatic veins. It's commonly used today for refractory variceal bleeding and ascites.

choices.text: Common hepatic duct, cystic duct, inferior surface of liver
Common hepatic duct, cystic artery, right hepatic artery

questions.text: The cystohepatic triangle  is bounded by:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Common hepatic duct, cystic duct, inferior surface of liver

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with brown pigment stones?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Biliary infection

Brown stones = infected bile → commonly seen in oriental cholangitis.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT an indication for prophylactic cholecystectomy in an asymptomatic patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Gallstones in a 35-year-old female

Asymptomatic gallstones do not need surgery unless specific high-risk features are present.

questions.text: Which liver segments are resected in extended cholecystectomy for Ca GB?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Standard extended resection involves GB + liver wedge of segments IVb+ V + lymphadenectomy
These are the segments directly adjacent to the gallbladder fossa.
Most likely to be involved via direct extension.

While the most commonly cited and traditional anatomical resection for gallbladder cancer is the bisegmentectomy of IVb and V, some surgeons and institutions do perform a resection of IVa and V.

questions.text: Which lymph nodes are commonly involved first in gallbladder carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Cystic and pericholedochal nodes

Lymph Node of Lund:
• Also called the cystic lymph node
• Located in Calot’s triangle, near the junction of the cystic duct and the common hepatic duct
• Drains the gallbladder directly
• It is a component of Option C, i.e., “Cystic and pericholedochal nodes”
So yes, Lund’s node is part of the lymph nodes described in Option C, making Option C the correct and complete answer.

questions.text: A well-defined, non-enhancing cystic lesion near the tail of pancreas with history of recent pancreatitis is most likely:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Pancreatic pseudocyst

Pseudocysts occur after acute pancreatitis, especially around 2–6 weeks, commonly in the tail, and have no epithelial lining.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with painless jaundice and palpable gallbladder. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Pancreatic head carcinoma

Courvoisier's sign = painless jaundice + palpable GB → classic for carcinoma head of pancreas compressing CBD.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a periampullary malignancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Hepatocellular carcinoma

Periampullary cancers include:
• Pancreatic head cancer
• Distal CBD cancer
• Ampullary cancer
• Duodenal (2nd part) cancer

questions.text: Whipple’s procedure is done for all except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Tail of pancreas tumor

Tail lesions require distal pancreatectomy, not Whipple (pancreaticoduodenectomy).

questions.text: Which pancreatic cystic lesion has malignant potential?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Mucinous cystadenoma

Mucinous cystic neoplasms are precancerous, often in body/tail of pancreas in females.

questions.text: A 6-week-old infant presents with persistent jaundice, pale stools, and dark urine. Liver is firm and enlarged. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Biliary atresia

Classic presentation of biliary atresia—jaundice beyond 2 weeks, clay-colored stools, and hepatomegaly.

questions.text: A child presents with abdominal pain, jaundice, and a palpable mass in the RUQ. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Classical triad of choledochal cyst = jaundice + abdominal pain + palpable RUQ mass.

questions.text: A 60-year-old with painless progressive jaundice and weight loss, USG shows dilated CBD and pancreatic duct ("double duct sign"). Most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Carcinoma head of pancreas

Double duct sign on imaging is classical for carcinoma of pancreatic head.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a feature of Mirizzi syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Presence of CBD stone

CBD stone is not present in Mirizzi; obstruction is from external compression

questions.text: In Bismuth classification, a stricture >2 cm below the hepatic duct confluence is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Type I

• Type I: >2 cm from confluence
• Type II: <2 cm
• Type III: No confluence, but right and left ducts visible
Type IV: Right and left ducts separate, not joined

questions.text: Intra-abdominal pressure above which ACS is diagnosed?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

questions.text: Which topical agent penetrates eschar and covers Pseudomonas?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Mafenide acetate

questions.text: According to Brisbane classification, right hepatectomy includes resection of which Couinaud segments?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Segments V, VI, VII, VIII

questions.text: Bridging veins rupture typically leads to:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Subdural hematoma

questions.text: Which is not a known risk factor for HCC?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Primary sclerosing cholangitis

PSC → cholangiocarcinoma, not HCC.
